escape.translation[0].definitions[0].def: to leave a place when someone is trying to catch you or stop you, or when there is a dangerous situation
escape.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: He broke down the locked door and escaped.
He escaped from prison in October.
escape.translation[0].definitions[1].def: to get away from a dangerous or bad situation
escape.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: They went to the hills to escape the summer heat.
A boy escaped unhurt when the fire in his room exploded.
The youth was trying to escape the clutches of two drunken female companions.
escape.translation[0].definitions[2].def: to avoid something bad or that you do not want to happen
escape.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: He narrowly escaped death in an avalanche.
The two passengers escaped serious injury.
They must not be allowed to escape justice.
It seemed impossible he would escape detection.
escape.translation[0].definitions[3].def: if gas, liquid, light, heat etc escapes from somewhere, it comes out
escape.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: Vents allow any steam to escape if the system overheats.
escape.translation[0].definitions[4].def: if a sound escapes from someone, they accidentally make that sound
escape.translation[0].definitions[4].exa: Holman let a weary sigh escape from his lips.
escape.translation[0].note_box[0].sectio: Some prisoners tried to escape, but most were recaptured or shot.
Both drivers were lucky to escape serious injury.
These terrorists must not be allowed to escape justice.
Some insects manage to escape detection by merging with the background.
He managed to escape the men’s clutches and run off.
The firemen narrowly escaped being killed by the explosion.
When the tunnel collapsed, the men were lucky to escape with their lives.
Two policemen were killed, but the president escaped unharmed.
The crew of the sinking vessel were lucky to escape alive.
escape.translation[0].note_box[1].sectio: to leave a place when someone is trying to catch you or stop you, or when there is a dangerous situation
The thief escaped through an upstairs window.
She managed to escape from her attacker and call the police.
get away
to escape from someone who is chasing you, especially when there is no chance that you will be caught. Get away is more informal than escape
The robbers got away but left plenty of clues at the scene.
Don’t let him get away!
break free/break away
to escape from someone who is holding you
She broke free and started running.
flee
to leave somewhere very quickly in order to escape from danger
Many people were forced to flee the country.
The two men fled before police arrived.
get out
to escape from a building or room
I was locked in the room and couldn’t get out.
break out
to escape from prison
The jail is so secure that no one has ever broken out of it.
abscond
to escape from a prison or institution where you are supposed to stay
Three prisoners who absconded have still not been found.
He absconded from a psychiatric hospital.
escape.translation[1].definitions[0].def: the act of getting away from a place, or a dangerous or bad situation
escape.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: The girl had no chance of escape.
Christina hoped it wouldn’t be too long before she could make her escape.
They had a lucky escape (=were lucky not to be hurt or killed) when a car crashed into the front of their house.
the firm’s narrow escape from bankruptcy
escape.translation[1].definitions[1].def: a way of forgetting about a bad or boring situation for a short time
escape.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: Travel can be an escape from the routine drudgery of life.
escape.translation[1].definitions[2].def: an amount of gas, liquid etc that accidentally comes out of the place where it is being kept, or an occasion when this happens
escape.translation[1].definitions[2].exa: The lid prevents the escape of poisonous gases.
escape.translation[1].note_box[0].headin: – Meaning 1: the act of getting away from a place, or a dangerous or bad situation
escape.translation[1].note_box[0].sectio: We planned our escape carefully and waited for just the right moment.
Walker grabbed her firmly by the wrist, preventing any chance of escape.
I had to make my escape before the guards returned.
She made several unsuccessful escape attempts before finally getting away.
You should have an escape plan in the event of a fire.
All their escape routes had been blocked.
The team had a narrow escape from relegation last season.
We had a lucky escape when a tree crashed through the ceiling.
Ellie had miraculous escape after a firework exploded in her hand.
She searched in vain for a means of escape.
The river offered our only hope of escape.
Dillinger handcuffed the deputy to the desk and made good his escape.
escape.translation[1].note_box[1].headin: – Meaning 2: a way of forgetting about a bad or boring situation for a short time
escape.translation[1].note_box[1].sectio: Drugs and alcohol are their only means of escape.
Bankruptcy offered his only escape route from mounting debt.
